bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, November 2, 1941

div1.p: Kean tells Truby about arrangements being made for the Jefferson Memorial and provides the information Truby requested concerning sanitary arrangements in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, November 2, 1941
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Nov. 2 1941
My dear Truby
div1.p:
I have taken much
more time than was necessary
to answer the few questions in
the slip which came with your
letter of the 24th Things were
happening here all last week
that took up my time. It was
an important week with the
T. J. Memorial in which we have
finally settled the question of
the inscriptions on the walls
of the Memorial which we have
been debating for over a year
and about which I had some
very decided notions. Then we
AC
T
2
have decided the size of the heroic
statue of T.J. which will stand in
the center of the temple. Then
there were teas and dinners
and visitors and various “must
do”. And when I got out my
diaries to find your answers I
read on and on, and finally
got slips of paper and jotted
down other things that I came
across which possibly might
interest you. I was often inter-
rupted, so I would lose my place
and my attention would be on
other things. Here is the result
8 slips. Do what you choose with
them. In case you are interested in
who are the commissioners of the T.J.M.
I have used a sheet of their stationery
AC
T
3
you will find the names on the back
of pagesslips VI & VII. Truby when I
read over the accounts of the delays,
refusals and stupidities of of Col. F. S.
Humphrey I got mad all over again
as I was in the spring of 1899 at the
dog-in-the manger behavior of Gen.
Humphrey about every thing relating
to the Medical Service. He even but
lied our chief Q. M. and Post Q. M.
at Marianao & the Barracks so
that they got to be nearly as bad
as he was.

Nov. 3. I found yesterday afternoon
a file of my sanitary reports,
routine and special, for 1899 &
1900 and spent all the afternoon
and evening up to 11.30 pm reading
them, they are of course much fuller
than my diary especially about the
4.
sewer. When the barracks were limed over on
July 1st 1899 to Gen. Lee for occupation by the
troops the latrines had simply a wheel
barrow under each seat but none of the
other arrangements and facilities necessary
to be provided for a dry earth system on
a great scale a large building where
the earth could be dried by baking if neces-
sary as in the rainy system & pulverized
and stored - a large bin in each
latine for a stock of clay dust and
scoops to handle it and a sewer
for the transportation & disposal of
the fwces after dusting. There were
no pantries and cupboards connected
with the kitchens or ice boxes or any place
to store food or any screens to protect it
from flies. There were 4 pages of important omis-
sions listed in the report of the Board of Survey
which would have to be remedied before the
buildings could be occupied in troops. Gen. Lee
stood firm and would not allow their occupation
by troops until they were all supplied.

5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.

I am afraid that the sewer will seen
to you to occupy an undue prominence
in my notes, but it was of immense
sanitary importance and besides it was
a test issue with the Q. M. Dept in Cuba
to decide if they should run the sanita-
tion and ignore the Med. Dept entirely
in these matters. Humphrey started
out with the latter idea and we beat
him in the end. President Theodore
Roosevelt was right in his scathing
criticism of Humphrey's inefficiency
in the embarkation of Shafters Army
at Tampa. It is an extraordinary
feat of hypnotism by that slick, clever
Irishman Gen. Weston that he persuaded
AC
T
6
T. R. that it would be an act of wonder-
ful magnanimity for him to appoint
Col. C. F. Humphrey to be Quarter Master
General of the Army. He was a
slick bluffer as such, but he had
learned to respect the Med. Dept.
and we had no trouble with him.
Loss to the lady. I inclose a copy
of circular no. 8. Hdqrs Dept of Western Cuba
